attributes.title: Isometric Neck Strength and Perceived Formidability
attributes.description: The current study aims to examine isometric neck strength as a predictor of perceived formidability, using data from Třebický et al. (2019).

q2.value:
It is hypothesised that isometric neck strength will predict perceived formidability, after comprehensively controlling for body composition (fat, muscle, bone), isometric strength (arm, knee, trunk, handgrip strength), age, height, beardedness, and spirometry measurements (forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volumne, peak expiratory flow).

We will not use the wins-to-fights ratio variable for additional analyses because this is problematically calculated (e.g., an individual who has been in two fights and has won both will have a ratio of 1, whereas a fighter who has been in 20 fights and has won 19 will arguably be a better fighter, but have a lower ratio, thus making this measure problematic).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The existing dataset is borrowed from Třebický et al. (2019).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The existing dataset is borrowed from Třebický et al. (2019).  It contains information on the mean formidability rating, fighter age, height, beardedness, body composition, isometric strength (handgrip, trunk, arm, knee, neck), wins-to-fights ratio, and wingate and spirometry measurements.  We will not use the wins-to-fights ratio variable because this is problematically calculated (e.g., an individual who has been in two fights and has won both will have a ratio of 1, whereas a fighter who has been in 20 fighters and has won 19 will arguably be a better fighter, but have a lower ratio, making this measure problematic).

question.value: This was described Třebický et al. (2019).

q11.value: This was described in Třebický et al. (2019).

q12.value: This was described in Třebický et al. (2019).

q13.value: This was described in Třebický et al. (2019).

question.value: This was described in Třebický et al. (2019).

Isometric strength measurements for the arm (mean measurements: flexion and extension), trunk (mean measurements: bend and forward), neck (mean measurements: bend and forward), and knee (mean measurements: flexion and extension) will be summed.  Handgrip strength only consists of one mean measurement, which will thus be used as it appears in the original dataset.

We will perform Pearson's correlations with age, height, beardedness, isometric strength (arm, handgrip, trunk, knee, neck), body composition (fat, muscle, bone) and spirometry (forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volume, peak expiratory flow) and perceived formidability.

We will employ simultaneous multiple regression with perceived formidability as the criterion, and isometric neck strength as the predictor.  We will comprehensively control for age, height, beardedness, isometric strength (arm, handgrip, trunk, knee), body composition (fat, muscle, bone) and spirometry (forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volume, peak expiratory flow).  We will include these specific, individual measurements of each facet of body composition and spirometry to provide a more complete picture of their relations with perceived formidability.  We will include spirometry given its association with neck strength and success in fighting-oriented sports (e.g., boxing).  We will control for beardedness given its association to perceived formidability, and we will control for isometric strength, body composition, and height in case isometric neck strength is an allometric feature (i.e., larger necks might signal formidability because stronger / taller / bigger people in general have larger necks, and stronger / taller / bigger people are perceived as more formidable).

q19.value: P-values must be less than .05 to reach statistical significance.  Two-tailed analyses will be used.

q20.value: No data will be excluded.  All data is as per Třebický et al. (2019).

attributes.title: Generalization of Center Embedding to Novel Lengths
attributes.description: An Artificial Language Learning experiment testing whether participants will generalize a grammatical pattern involving center embedding to longer sequences than they have seen during acquisition of this pattern.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Generalization of Center Embedding to Novel Lengths

other.value:
We will also repeat the between-condition comparisons for the subsets of the test set that are of greater length than seen during training. That is, for both the category (ii) and category (iii) examples of greater length than seen during training, we will run a mixed-effects logistic regression, where the dependent variable is whether participants correctly classified whether a sequence is a valid member of the language, with a fixed effect for condition and by-item and by-participant random intercepts. We will use a chi-square test (in R) to evaluate the overall effect of condition; if this is significant, we will then use the R package multcomp to run comparisons between each pair of conditions. We predict that the same ranking of conditions will arise for these longer examples as we predicted for shorter examples: random ordering with uninformative buttons < starting small with uninformative buttons < {random ordering with informative buttons, starting small with informative buttons}. We operationalize that prediction in a similar way as we did for the shorter examples: learners in one condition will be said to perform significantly better than learners in a second condition if for at least 1 of the 2 categories learners in the first condition significantly outperform learners in the second condition, but learners in the second condition do not significantly outperform the learners in the first condition for either category. Along similar lines, learners in two conditions will be said to have no significant difference if, for both of these categories, there is no significant difference in performance between the two conditions.

To allow for the possibility that some participants may have failed to learn even the basic properties of the language (e.g., due to inattentiveness), we will repeat the same analyses specified above but with the exclusion criterion of excluding participants who scored below 75% on a subset of the test set that we have designated to be easy (such that any participant who has learned the basic properties of the sequences they have seen should be able to score well on this subset). The subset to be used for this purpose is subset (i) described in the previous section, which contains 20 test items. The accuracy level of 75% was chosen as the minimum score x such that achieving a score of x or above has a probability less than 5% under a binomial model with p(success) = 0.5 (i.e., the probability of success that participants would have if guessing by chance).

The statistical tests that we have specified above follow the maximal effect structure justified by the experimental setup. If the model does not converge with this effect structure, we will follow the standard approaches in backing off from this effect structure (e.g., taking out random intercepts).

sample.value: Following experiments done using a similar paradigm in Poletiek et al. (2018) we will collect observations from 50 participants per condition, for a total of 200 participants.

analyses.value:
Our test set contains 3 subsets of trials: (i) one subset that tests whether participants have learned that there can be no elements of class B before an element of class A, (ii) one subset that tests whether participants have learned that the number of B’s must match the number of A’s, and (iii) one subset that tests whether participants have learned the dependencies that exist between symmetrically-matched A’s and B’s. To test whether participants generalize to greater lengths than seen during training, subsets (ii) and (iii) contain some examples longer than any seen during training as well as some examples whose lengths are less than or equal to the maximum length seen during training. 

For each of these 3 test subsets, to test our hypotheses about comparisons between our four conditions, we will run a mixed-effects logistic regression, where the dependent variable is whether participants correctly classified whether a sequence is a valid member of the language. As these hypotheses only refer to learning of the center embedded pattern as it applies to sequences of lengths less than or equal to the maximum length seen during training, to test these hypotheses we will use the subset of the test set that falls within this length range (i.e., excluding the sequences longer than any seen during training). To test whether the condition that a participant is assigned to facilitates learning in the ways specified above, we will include a fixed effect of condition. We will also include by-item and by-participant random intercepts. We will use a chi-square test (in R) to evaluate the overall effect of condition; if this is significant, we will then use the R package multcomp to run comparisons between each pair of conditions.

The rest of our hypotheses deal not with comparisons between conditions but rather comparisons with chance performance. To test these hypotheses, we will subset the test set based on the category of example (i.e., categories (i), (ii), and (iii) described above) and based on whether the examples are longer than the maximum length seen during training or not. This leads to 5 subsets: category (i) examples (all of which are within the length bounds seen during training), category (ii) examples that are less than or equal to the maximum length seen during training, category (ii) examples that are longer than the maximum length seen during training, category (iii) examples that are less than or equal to the maximum length seen during training, and category (iii) examples that are longer than the maximum length seen during training. For each of these 5 subsets, and for each of the 4 conditions, we will run an intercepts-only mixed-effects logistic regression, including by-participant and by-item random intercepts, to test whether performance on each subset within each training condition is significantly above chance. Finally, to check for whether there is a significant difference in performance based on whether a sequence was longer than the lengths seen during training, for both of the categories that vary in this respect (category (ii) and category (iii)) and for each of the 4 conditions, we will run a mixed-effects logistic regression with a fixed effect for whether the sequence is of a greater length than seen during training, as well as by-participant and by-item random intercepts, and a by-participant random slope for length.

outliers.value: For the main analyses specified above, we will not exclude any observations. See below for the description of a secondary analysis that will involve excluding some data.

dependent.value: The dependent variable is whether participants accurately label a sequence as being a valid sequence in the language they have been taught or being an invalid sequence in this language. This variable is a binary outcome variable: accurate or inaccurate. We will test which sequences learners believe to belong in the language by presenting them with sequences and asking them whether each sequence is valid or not.

conditions.value: There will be 4 conditions: starting small with informative buttons, starting small with uninformative buttons, random order with informative buttons, and random order with uninformative buttons. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of these 4 conditions.

hypothesis.value:
When humans acquire languages, they generalize patterns from the utterances they have encountered to novel utterances and even to novel types of utterances (Chomsky 1965, 1980). The ways that humans generalize provide evidence for the inductive biases which guide language learning, where an inductive bias is any means for choosing one generalization over another (Mitchell 1980). We focus on one particular type of generalization: generalization to longer sequences than have been seen during acquisition. Because language acquisition proceeds over a finite set of utterances, the set of utterances from which learners learn must have some maximum length, yet the languages that humans acquire are generally taken to be unbounded; indeed, this unboundedness is traditionally viewed as one of the key properties of language (Hockett 1963). We investigate such generalization in an experimental setting by training participants on sequences with a certain maximum length and then testing them on sequences of a greater length. We hypothesize that participants will generalize the syntactic patterns that they have learned to sequences of greater length than they have seen before. 

We use an artificial language learning paradigm, in which participants are taught a simple language in a controlled way and are then tested on what they have learned. The language we have chosen for this purpose is the language of center-embedded pairs of words, such as “A1 A2 A3 B3 B2 B1,” where there are two categories of words (category A and category B) and where each word has a symmetrically opposite word that it depends on (e.g., A2 and B2 depend on each other). This type of language has been the focus of extensive past work in artificial language learning. In past work, learners are shown examples of such sequences and are then tested on whether they have learned certain properties of these sequences, particularly the property that no element of category B can precede an element of category A (Fitch and Hauser 2004); the property that there must be the same number of A’s as B’s (Hochmann, Azadpour, and Mehler 2008); and the property that symmetric pairs of words depend on each other (Perruchet and Rey 2005). However, few works have tested whether people generalize this pattern to greater lengths than were seen during training: Gentner et al. (2006) investigated this question in songbirds, but not in humans; one experiment in Poletiek (2002) investigated this question but did not get clear evidence of learning even in the lengths participants had seen; another experiment of Poletiek (2002), and the experiments of Cho et al. (2011), also investigated this question with humans but only found generalization to novel lengths when there was not a clean separation between training and testing, such that it is unclear if participants actually were generalizing to longer sequences or learning from the testing trials. 

In order to test whether participants generalize this pattern to greater lengths than they have seen, we must ensure that they learn the pattern for at least the lengths that they have seen, and past work has found that it is challenging to get participants to learn this pattern (de Vries et al. 2008). One manipulation that has been found to reliably help in the learning of this pattern is starting small, in which the training set is arranged in order from small sequences to large ones (Lai and Poletiek 2011, Poletiek et al. 2018). This finding from past work motivates a secondary hypothesis that we will also test: We hypothesize that the reason that starting small is beneficial is that it helps learners learn the relevant features of words present in the language, and that this is the sole reason why starting small is beneficial. By “the relevant features”, we mean which words belong to category A vs. category B, and which members of category A can depend on which members of category B. These features are more salient in shorter examples than in longer examples, so initial exposure to only short examples can help highlight these features. Under this hypothesis, it is the learning of these features, rather than the staged nature of the input per se, that facilitates learning of the language. One motivation for this hypothesis is that past work has shown that humans readily learn a mirror language (i.e., a language of even-length palindromes) (Jiang et al. 2018); the main difference between this mirror language and the language we investigate is that the language we investigate requires the learning of relevant word features whereas the mirror language does not. We believe that this difference is what makes the language we investigate so much harder to learn than the mirror language, and this is why we predict that the learning of these features is the crucial aspect of learning that has thwarted participants in non-starting-small settings, and that once learners are armed with knowledge of these features they will readily learn the rest of the language (as they do with the mirror language).

To test this secondary hypothesis, we introduce a new condition that is meant to provide strong cues to word features in a different way than starting small. This is achieved through the arrangement of the buttons that participants use to reproduce the sequences shown to them during training; we will use both an “informative buttons” setting in which the arrangement of these buttons provides cues to the features present in the language, and an “uninformative buttons” setting in which the buttons do not provide cues to this information. We will also vary whether training starts small or involves randomly-ordered sequences, to give 4 conditions: starting small with informative buttons, starting small with uninformative buttons, random ordering with informative buttons, and random ordering with uninformative buttons.

Our two hypotheses can thus be summarized together as follows: the main difficulty that learners have in learning a center-embedded pattern is learning the features of the words used to instantiate that pattern, such that any method that makes these features salient will facilitate learning of center embedding, with the degree of facilitation determined by how salient the method makes these features (secondary hypothesis); but when learners do learn the center-embedded pattern for sequences with a certain maximum length they will naturally extend it to longer sequences than they have seen before (main hypothesis). We will operationalize successful knowledge of the center-embedded pattern as the ability to discriminate between strings that fit the pattern from those that do not, for strings up to the maximum length that has been presented during training (call this length N). Our test set includes three categories of example; for us to conclude that successful learning of the center-embedded pattern has occurred, performance must be above chance on all three categories. We will further operationalize the prediction that participants will generalize this knowledge to greater lengths as follows: if participants correctly discriminate strings up to length N, then they will also correctly discriminate strings up to length N+2. The particular types of strings that will be used to test identification of strings that do not fit the pattern will be discussed in more detail below.

The specific predictions that these hypotheses make are that the learners in the “random ordering with uninformative buttons” condition will not learn the center embedded pattern, but that the learners in the other conditions will (because of the ways that these conditions facilitate the learning of the relevant features) and that learners in these conditions will also extend this pattern to novel lengths. Of our two methods for making the features salient, we predict that the informative buttons will make the relevant features more salient than starting small, and that having both forms of assistance together will not be more helpful than having the informative buttons alone (i.e., that the benefits of starting small will be redundant when paired with the benefits of the informative buttons). Thus, we also predict that learners in the “random order with informative buttons” condition will learn the center embedded pattern significantly better than learners in the “starting small with uninformative buttons” condition, and that learners will perform significantly better in the “starting small with informative buttons” condition than in the “starting small with uninformative buttons” condition, but not significantly better than in the “random ordering with informative buttons” condition. Overall, then, we predict the following ranking among our 4 conditions with respect to how well learners in each condition will learn the center embedded pattern: random ordering with uninformative buttons < starting small with uninformative buttons < {random ordering with informative buttons, starting small with informative buttons}. 

For the purposes of these predictions, our test set is divided into 5 categories (3 categories of sequences whose lengths are less than or equal to the maximum length seen during training, and 2 categories of sequences longer than those seen during training). With respect to these 5 categories, the predictions described in the previous paragraph will be operationalized as follows: For learners in the “random ordering with uninformative buttons” condition, there will be at least 1 of the 3 categories with lengths less than or equal to the maximum length used during training for which these learners do not exceed chance performance, and there will be at least 1 of the 2 categories with lengths greater than seen during training for which these learners do not exceed chance performance. For learners in the other 3 conditions, performance will exceed chance for all 5 categories. Finally, regarding the predictions about which conditions lead to more effective learning than others, we will operationalize this as follows: learners in one condition will be said to have learned the center embedded pattern significantly better than learners in a second condition if there is at least 1 of the 3 categories with lengths less than or equal to the maximum length used during training for which learners in the first condition significantly outperform learners in the second condition, but there are no categories among those 3 categories for which learners in the second condition significantly outperform the learners in the first condition. Along similar lines, learners in two conditions will be said to have no significant difference if, for all 3 of these categories, there is no significant difference in performance between the two conditions.

These features are more salient in shorter examples than in longer examples, so initial exposure to only short examples can help highlight these features. Under this hypothesis, it is the learning of these features, rather than the staged nature of the input per se, that facilitates learning of the language. One motivation for this hypothesis is that past work has shown that humans readily learn a mirror language (i.e., a language of even-length palindromes) (Jiang et al. 2018); the main difference between this mirror language and the language we investigate is that the language we investigate requires the learning of relevant word features whereas the mirror language does not. We believe that this difference is what makes the language we investigate so much harder to learn than the mirror language, and this is why we predict that the learning of these features is the crucial aspect of learning that has thwarted participants in non-starting-small settings, and that once learners are armed with knowledge of these features they will readily learn the rest of the language (as they do with the mirror language).

To test this secondary hypothesis, we introduce a new condition that is meant to provide strong cues to word features in a different way than starting small. This is achieved through the arrangement of the buttons that participants use to reproduce the sequences shown to them during training; we will use both an “informative buttons” setting in which the arrangement of these buttons provides cues to the features present in the language, and an “uninformative buttons” setting in which the buttons do not provide cues to this information. We will also vary whether training starts small or involves randomly-ordered sequences, to give 4 conditions: starting small with informative buttons, starting small with uninformative buttons, random ordering with informative buttons, and random ordering with uninformative buttons.

Our two hypotheses can thus be summarized together as follows: the main difficulty that learners have in learning a center-embedded pattern is learning the features of the words used to instantiate that pattern, such that any method that makes these features salient will facilitate learning of center embedding, with the degree of facilitation determined by how salient the method makes these features (secondary hypothesis); but when learners do learn the center-embedded pattern for sequences with a certain maximum length they will naturally extend it to longer sequences than they have seen before (main hypothesis). We will operationalize successful knowledge of the center-embedded pattern as the ability to discriminate between strings that fit the pattern from those that do not, for strings up to the maximum length that has been presented during training (call this length N). Our test set includes three categories of example; for us to conclude that successful learning of the center-embedded pattern has occurred, performance must be above chance on all three categories. We will further operationalize the prediction that participants will generalize this knowledge to greater lengths as follows: if participants correctly discriminate strings up to length N, then they will also correctly discriminate strings up to length N+2. The particular types of strings that will be used to test identification of strings that do not fit the pattern will be discussed in more detail below.

The specific predictions that these hypotheses make are that the learners in the “random ordering with uninformative buttons” condition will not learn the center embedded pattern, but that the learners in the other conditions will (because of the ways that these conditions facilitate the learning of the relevant features) and that learners in these conditions will also extend this pattern to novel lengths. Of our two methods for making the features salient, we predict that the informative buttons will make the relevant features more salient than starting small, and that having both forms of assistance together will not be more helpful than having the informative buttons alone (i.e., that the benefits of starting small will be redundant when paired with the benefits of the informative buttons). Thus, we also predict that learners in the “random order with informative buttons” condition will learn the center embedded pattern significantly better than learners in the “starting small with uninformative buttons” condition, and that learners will perform significantly better in the “starting small with informative buttons” condition than in the “starting small with uninformative buttons” condition, but not significantly better than in the “random ordering with informative buttons” condition. Overall, then, we predict the following ranking among our 4 conditions with respect to how well learners in each condition will learn the center embedded pattern: random ordering with uninformative buttons < starting small with uninformative buttons < {random ordering with informative buttons, starting small with informative buttons}. 

For the purposes of these predictions, our test set is divided into 5 categories (3 categories of sequences whose lengths are less than or equal to the maximum length seen during training, and 2 categories of sequences longer than those seen during training). With respect to these 5 categories, the predictions described in the previous paragraph will be operationalized as follows: For learners in the “random ordering with uninformative buttons” condition, there will be at least 1 of the 3 categories with lengths less than or equal to the maximum length used during training for which these learners do not exceed chance performance, and there will be at least 1 of the 2 categories with lengths greater than seen during training for which these learners do not exceed chance performance. For learners in the other 3 conditions, performance will exceed chance for all 5 categories. Finally, regarding the predictions about which conditions lead to more effective learning than others, we will operationalize this as follows: learners in one condition will be said to have learned the center embedded pattern significantly better than learners in a second condition if there is at least 1 of the 3 categories with lengths less than or equal to the maximum length used during training for which learners in the first condition significantly outperform learners in the second condition, but there are no categories among those 3 categories for which learners in the second condition significantly outperform the learners in the first condition. Along similar lines, learners in two conditions will be said to have no significant difference if, for all 3 of these categories, there is no significant difference in performance between the two conditions.

attributes.title: Adverse effects of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in COVID-19 and other viral respiratory infections: Rapid Review
attributes.description:
Background
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are among the most commonly used drugs, and have a wide range of uses, including treatment of acute and chronic pain, fever, and inflammations of infectious and non-infectious etiology. NSAIDs include unselective cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors (such as ibuprofen, aspirin (acetylsalicylate), diclofenac and naproxen) as well as selective COX 2 inhibitors (such as Celecoxib, Rofecoxib, Etoricoxib, Lumiracoxib, and Valecoxib). 

Concerns have been raised that NSAIDs may be associated with an increased risk for adverse effects when used in patients with acute viral respiratory infections, including COVID-19 (caused by the virus SARS-CoV-2), Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS, caused by SARS-CoV), Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS, caused by MERS-CoV), and other coronavirus infections. These concerns apply both to the use of NSAIDs prior to the infection, and to the use of NSAID during the infection.

Objectives
To assess the effects of prior and current use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in patients with acute viral respiratory infections on acute severe adverse events (including mortality, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute organ failure and opportunistic infections), on acute healthcare utilization (including hospitalization, intensive care unit (ICU) admission, supplemental oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation) as well as on quality of life and long-term survival. 

Setting of the review question and protocol development
The overall review question was set by the World Health Organization (WHO), which commissioned this review. At WHO, clinical experts and methodologists were involved in defining the review question. The protocol was developed by PvP and ER drawing on Cochrane Rapid Review guidance [1] and with input from Susan Norris (WHO), Gerald Gartlehner (Cochrane Austria) as well as AM, JB, JMS, KS, LMP and SD. Outcomes were set by WHO and refined by PvP and ER drawing on guidance from the WHO Working Group on the clinical characterization of COVID-19 infection (Annex 1) [2] and Susan Norris.

question.value:
Eligibility
Tables 1 and 2 provide an overview of inclusion and exclusion criteria.
Studies that include both patients with conditions considered in this review (i.e. acute viral respiratory infections or conditions commonly caused by respiratory viruses) and patients with other conditions (e.g. bacterial infections, conditions treated with antibiotics) will be included at title and abstract screening stage. We will decide at full text screening stage on how to proceed with these.
As the methodological approach to monitoring adverse events as well as their occurrence is often poorly reported in peer-reviewed publications, we will adopt an inclusive approach. During full text screening we will take note of all studies that do not explicitly report on severe adverse events or the method to identify these but where it may be possible to assume that no such events occurred (e.g. because the study reports adverse events classified as mild or moderate or because the study reports that no severe side effects were recorded). After full text screening we will decide on a consistent approach with regard to these studies. 
Secondary outcomes are of interest to WHO but we will not screen for these during title/abstract or full-text screening. Where a study reporting on a primary outcome also provides data on these secondary outcomes, we will attempt to extract them if this is feasible within the time frame of the review.
Studies that report both outcomes considered in this review (e.g. acute complications) and outcomes not considered in this review (e.g. long-term gastrointestinal adverse effects) will be included, but data extraction will be limited to relevant outcomes.
We will include any systematic empirical study design reporting primary data on at least 10 patients (Table 1). For COVID-19, SARS and MERS, studies of any size will be eligible for inclusion.

Search methods for identification of studies
We will perform searches in MEDLINE and EMBASE, using the Ovid search interface. We will use existing systematic and narrative reviews and included studies to perform backward- and forward-citation searches in Scopus. In addition, the review team will search the WHO Database of publications on coronavirus disease (COVID-19) [3].
Our search strategy is based on two sets of search terms (NSAIDs, and viral respiratory infections), and was reviewed by an experienced information specialist (Irma Klerings). All searches will be conducted in English and abstracts screened in English only. Database searches will be limited to studies published in English or German. For studies on the current COVID-19 outbreak, we will consider studies in English, French, German and Italian. No restriction based on the year of publication will be applied. The MEDLINE and EMBASE search strategies as well as an initial set of systematic and narrative reviews and other key publications used for the backward- and forward-citation searches are shown in Annexes 3-5.

q11.value:
Study selection
After removal of duplicate studies, we will perform a multistage screening process to select those studies which meet the inclusion criteria:
• Stage 1, screening of titles and abstracts: One review author will assess the titles and abstracts of all identified records. 20% of all titles and abstracts will be independently assessed by a second review author. Depending on the number of additional eligible studies identified by the second review author and taking into account time constraints, we will decide if the remaining titles and abstracts will also be screened by a second review author.
• Stage 2, screening of full-texts: One review author will assess the full texts of all identified records selected in step 1. In cases deemed unclear or ambiguous by the first review author, advice from a second review author will be sought. 20% of all full texts will be independently assessed by a second review author. Depending on the number of additional eligible studies identified by the second review author and taking into account time constraints, we will decide if the remaining full texts will also be screened by a second reviewer.

As adverse effects are not always mentioned in the title and abstract of publications, we will adopt a very inclusive approach in stage 1, and take forward all abstracts which make reference to NSAID use in patients with acute respiratory viral infections or conditions commonly caused by respiratory viral infections. We will also take forward abstracts of studies with a focus on adverse effects of NSAIDs in general, if we suspect that they may provide information on viral respiratory infections or relevant conditions in their full text, even if these are not mentioned explicitly in the title or abstract.
EndNote will be used to collect and de-duplicate studies. For the screening of titles and abstracts we will use Rayyan, web-based applications for facilitating citation screening for systematic reviews (Elmagarmid 2014; Rathbone 2015). At stage two of the screening process, we will document the reasons for exclusion using Microsoft Excel.

question.value:
Data extraction and management
One review author will extract study characteristics and study data to the data extraction form, shown in Annex 6. 
The data extraction form will be pilot-tested by the review team. As detailed in this extraction form, with respect to the study population, among other issues, we will pay attention to the characterization of the viral respiratory infection (i.e. disease, severity, pathogen, share of participants with viral respiratory infection) and any pre-existing conditions or co-morbidities. 
With respect to the intervention and comparison, we will extract detailed information regarding NSAID use, notably regarding the specific drug used (Annex 2), type of application (i.e. intravenous or oral), reason for NSAID use, prescription vs. over-the-counter use, and initiation of NSAID use prior to or during the viral respiratory infection. One review author will assess all data extraction forms and classify NSAIDs based on their mechanism of action (unselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors, and selective cyclooxygenase 2 inhibitors).
With respect to outcomes, we will extract information on all primary outcomes, i.e. acute severe adverse events, acute healthcare utilization, long term survival and quality of life as detailed under the inclusion criteria above. In addition, where available and time permitting, we will also extract information on the following secondary outcomes:	
• Laboratory findings: C-reactive protein (CRP), ferritin, leukocyte counts and others
• Imaging / radiologic findings: CT chest scan, chest x-ray and others

Risk of bias assessment
One review author will assess risk of bias of included studies. We will use the Tool to Assess Risk of Bias in Case Control Studies developed by the Clarity Group at McMaster University for case-control studies [4], and the Cochrane risk of bias tool adapted by the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care (EPOC) group for all remaining study designs [5].
The Tool to Assess Risk of Bias in Case Control Studies developed by the Clarity Group at McMaster University is based on the following five questions:
1. Can we be confident in the assessment of exposure?
2. Can we be confident that cases had developed the outcome of interest and controls had not?
3. Were the cases (those who were exposed and developed the outcome of interest) properly selected?
4. Were the controls (those who were exposed and did not develop the outcome of interest) properly selected?
5. Were cases and controls matched according to important prognostic variables or was statistical adjustment carried out for those variables?
For each of these questions, one of the following answers is given:
• Definitely yes (low risk of bias)
• Probably yes (probably low risk of bias)
• Probably no (probably high risk of bias)
• Definitely no (high risk of bias)
The Cochrane EPOC Risk of Bias tool includes the following nine criteria:
1. Random sequence generation (selection bias)
2. Allocation concealment (selection bias)
3. Similarity of baseline outcome measurements (selection bias)
4. Similarity of other baseline characteristics (selection and performance bias)
5. Incomplete outcome data (attrition bias)
6. Blinding (performance and detection bias)
7. Contamination (performance bias)
8. Selective reporting (reporting bias)
9. Other potential sources of bias
For each of these criteria, one of the following assessments is given:
• Low risk of bias: plausible bias unlikely to alter the results
• Unclear risk of bias: plausible bias that raises some doubt about the results
• High risk of bias: plausible bias that seriously weakens confidence in the results
In applying the tool we will follow relevant instructions as provided by EPOC (EPOC 2015) and the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2017a). We will present risk of bias findings either in tables or by adapting the traffic light scheme used by Cochrane.

Assessment of the certainty of evidence
We will use GRADE to assess the certainty of evidence of primary outcomes. The assessment of the certainty of evidence will be done by two review authors, and the findings discussed among the review team.
In GRADE, the certainty of evidence can be understood as the extent to which one can be confident that the true effect of an intervention lies on one side of a specified threshold, or within a chosen range (Hultcrantz 2017). Within the GRADE approach, the certainty of evidence is assessed based on a number of factors which can decrease or increase the level of evidence. Traditionally, evidence from RCTs starts as high certainty evidence in GRADE, and evidence from all other study designs starts as low certainty.
There are four possible levels of evidence:
• High certainty: Further research is very unlikely to change our confidence in the estimate of effect.
• Moderate certainty: Further research is likely to have an important impact on our confidence in the estimate of effect and may change the estimate.
• Low certainty: Further research is very likely to have an important impact on our confidence in the estimate of effect and is likely to change the estimate.
• Very low certainty: Any estimate of effect is uncertain.
There are five factors that can lead to a downgrading of the level of evidence. If one of these factors is found to exist, it is classified either as serious (downgrading by one level) or as very serious (downgrading by two levels):
• Risk of bias of individual studies (limitations in the design and implementation of available studies, suggesting high likelihood of bias).
• Indirectness of evidence (indirect population, intervention, control, outcomes).
• Unexplained heterogeneity or inconsistency of results (including problems with subgroup analyses).
• Imprecision of results (wide confidence intervals).
• High probability of publication bias.
There are three factors increasing the certainty of evidence, each of which can lead to an upgrading of the level of evidence:
• Large magnitude of effect (upgrading by one or two levels).
• All plausible confounding would reduce a demonstrated effect or suggest a spurious effect when results show no effect (upgrading by one level).
• Dose‐response gradient (upgrading by one level).

Evidence synthesis
We will summarize the findings of the included studies narratively and with tables. If we find two or more sufficiently homogenous studies, we will conduct meta-analyses and present forest plots.
As much as possible within the timeframe and sensible in terms of the number of studies identified, we will conduct stratified analyses based on the following criteria:
• Pathogen/disease group (COVID-19, SARS, MERS, other coronaviruses, other viral respiratory infections)
• Age (elderly > 65 years, adults 18-65 years; adolescents 12-17 years, children 6-12 years, <6 years)
• Sex
• Severity of the acute viral respiratory infection (mild, moderate, severe)
• With or without acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
• Co-morbidities (pre-existing cardiovascular disease (including hypertension and ischemic heart disease), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, diabetes mellitus, renal disease, rheumatic diseases, prior allergic or hypersensitive reactions to NSAIDs including Reye’s syndrome)
• Type of NSAID used (unselective COX inhibitors, selective cyclooxygenase 2 inhibitors)
• Specific substance used (e.g. ibuprofen, aspirin, etc.) and dose (high vs. low)
• Prior use (incl. short-term/intermittent vs. chronic/long-term) vs. use during acute viral respiratory infection
All data presented in the final review manuscript in the narrative synthesis, in tables or in meta-analyses and forest plots will be independently checked by a second review author.

attributes.title: Accessible Vs. extreme automatic attitudes
attributes.description: A plan for study 2 of this project.

summary.value:
Accessible vs. Extreme automatic attitudes 2 - study plan

Purpose
The purpose of the present research is to examine the effects of practice and extremity of evaluation on the automatic activation of the evaluation as measures by the EPT.

 Background
A classic finding in the field of automatic attitudes is the finding that an accessible attitude toward an object prompts an automatic activation of the evaluation upon encountering the attitude object (Fazio, Sanbonmatsu, Powell, & Kardes, 1986). One research tested the relation between accessible evaluations of nouns (e.g., divorce and baby) and the automatic activation of these evaluations (Fazio et al., 1986). In two studies, accessible evaluations were operationalized as relatively fast self-reported evaluations. In a third study, accessible evaluations were manipulated by rehearsal (evaluating a noun five different times versus making a non-evaluative judgment of a noun). Automatic evaluation was measured in an evaluative priming task. In that task, participant categorized adjectives as good or bad. Before each adjective, a noun appeared. The index of automatic evaluation of each noun was the size of the expected priming effect: faster categorization of adjectives of valence that was congruent with the valence of the prime noun than of adjectives of the other valence. The study found that nouns with more accessible evaluations had a stronger priming effect in the evaluative priming task. Accessible attitudes in this context were defined as attitudes that required relatively short time to activate or were manipulated by rehearsing the evaluation (Fazio et al., 1986). Thus, the faster the evaluation was produced or the more training the evolution received, the more likely it was to be activated unintentionally. 

One interesting finding that was frequently observed in these experiments is the correlation between accessibility and extremity. Specifically, it was found that accessible evaluations (evaluations that are activated relatively quickly) tend to be quite extreme (Judd & kulak, 1980; Fazio & Williams, 1986; Bargh, Chaiken, Govender, & Pratto, 1992; Giner-sorola, 2001). The size of the relationship between accessibility and extremity was found to be somewhere between (-.3) - (-.53), thus the two constructs are substantially related but not redundant with each other (Powell & Fazio, 1984). 

In a previous research we set out to test how manipulations of amount of practice (accessibility) and of valence extremity would manifest in an unintentional evaluation. Unintentional evaluation can vary in its extremity and in the likelihood that it would be activated. A straightforward hypothesis is that extremity would be determined by the extremity of the evaluative information about the object, whereas the likelihood of unintentional activation would be determined by practice in making the evaluation. Because the EP effect is the average difference between incompatible and compatible trials, the effect frequency and its extant are intertwined. Thus, the purpose of that research was to examine whether it is possible to untangle the specific effects of evaluation practice and evaluation extremity on unintentional evaluation.

 The present research
 The results of AutoExt1 showed that practice and extremity affected implicit evaluations in the EP. Namely, the more practice in evaluation an object received, or, the more extreme the evaluation was, the more positive the EP score for that object was. As for explicit evaluations, we found that extremity but not practice affected the final explicit ratings of the targets. However, when looking at rating change (the difference in rating from the initial rating at the beginning of the experiment to the last rating at the end of the experiment), we found that practice increased the direct ratings. This finding made it difficult to determine how practice and extremity influenced the automaticity of the evaluations because increases in practice (and extremity) changed self-reported evaluations. For that reason, in the present research, we will balance the amount of exposure each target received so that each target will be presented equally, but the number of evaluations will vary according to condition. In addition, participants will have to evaluate targets based on description of behaviors instead of attractiveness to faces because we suspect that attraction might be somewhat automatic to begin with, which leaves less room for automatization manipulations.

 Procedure
 Participants will learn about 8 different target men. For each man, they will be presented with 6 behaviors that are attributed to that person, an image of the man and his name. The 8 men will vary on to three variables; (1) valence (positive vs. negative), (2) extremity (Extreme: 5 behaviors corresponding with valence and 1 neutral behavior, Moderate: 2 behaviors corresponding with valence and 4 neutral behaviors) and (3) practice (16 vs. 4 evaluations). After the learning phase participants will start to practice evaluating the men. To keep the amount of exposure to the men constant, we will use two questions, one evaluative (i.e., how likable is this person in your opinion) and one non-evaluative (where do you think this man lives, a city or the countryside), and we will manipulate the amount of times each character is presented with the evaluative question. The practice phase will comprise of 4 blocks of 5 trials for each man, for a total of 40 trials in each block, and 160 trials in the whole task. In the high practice condition, on each block participants will be asked to evaluate the target 4 times (for a total of 16 throughout the practice) and answer the non-evaluative question only once (a total of 4 times throughout the practice). In the low practice condition the ratio of the question presentation will be reversed so that participants will answer the non-evaluative question 16 times throughout the experiment and the evaluative question only 4 times. To sum up the different conditions, we will have 8 men representing 8 conditions; extremely positive with long practice, extremely positive with short practice, moderately positive with long practice, moderately positive with short practice, extremely negative with long practice, extremely negative with short practice, moderately negative with long practice, moderately negative with short practice.
After learning about the men and practicing evaluating them, participants will complete an evaluative priming task. Within each of the EPT’s three blocks, each man will appear four times before positive targets and four times before negative targets, for a total of 64 trials. In total, each man will appear in 24 trials, 12 before positive targets and 12 before negative targets. After the EPT, participants will be asked to rate their liking toward to 8 men. Lastly, to examine the quality of learning, we will tell participants that some men were characterized by 5 positive behaviors and 1 neutral, some by 2 positive and 4 neutral behaviors, some by 2 negative and 4 neutral behaviors, and some by 5 negative and 1 neutral information and ask them by to try to recall what type of information combination was provided for each of the eight men.

Stimuli
 8 Names[1]:  David, Michael, Chris, Kevin, Brian, James, Robert, Paul

 14 Positive behaviors[2]:

20 Neutral behaviors[3]:

        	14 Negative behaviors[4]:
Yelled at his parents over the phone	2.77
Cut in front of some people in line to the metro (city)	2.56
Became upset and broke some dishes	2.52
Shoplifted an inexpensive item from a department store (city)	2.50
Criticized others because they weren't wearing fashionable clothes (city)	2.41
Dented the fender of a parked car and didn't leave his name	2.33
Insulted his assistant at work	2.07
Was arrested for selling heroin to a teenager	2.05
Drove through a red light at a potentially dangerous intersection (city)	2.04
Threw a rock at a dog that was barking (country)	1.93
Smoked on a crowded bus (city)	1.90
Made fun of a colleague who has a speech impediment	1.62
Stole money and jewelry from his relatives	1.54
Likes to pick fights with people that are physically weaker than him	1.48

       Learning phase
	In the attitude formation part, participants will learn about the men. Each man (name+face) will be presented with his behaviours presented one after the other consecutively, for a total of 6 trial (* 8 men = 48 trials). During the initial learning phase the trials will pass automatically, and each trial will remain for 5000 ms. After exposing participants to all the information, in the next block participants will see each man with all of his information. The trials in this block will remain on the screen until participants press to continue. 
	
Practice
During practice participants will be presented with a man (name+face) and a question to answer, either an evaluative question or a non-evaluaitve question. In 4 blocks, within each of the four conditions (likeability levels), half of the men will be evaluated 4 times (total of 16 evaluations) and asked a non-evaluative question once (total of 4 non-evaluations), and the other half will be evaluated once (total of 4 evaluations) and asked a non-evaluative question 4 times (total of 16 non-evaluations). Each block will be comprised of 5 mini-blocks  (that will be sampled randomly) in which all the men will appear once (Thus, 8 trials per mini-block). Additionally, before blocks 2,3,4 we will present participants with the men and their information again, to refresh their memory. 

         	EPT
Participants will complete an evaluative priming task with the 8 men:
Within each of the task’s three blocks, each man will appear four times before positive targets and four times before negative targets, for a total of 64 trials on each block (total of 192 trials in the task). Overall each man will appear in 24 trials, 12 before positive targets and 12 before negative targets. The trial sequence will be based on a recent Project Implicit study in our lab that showed good sensitivity to quite nuanced attitudes:
·       Fixation duration: 500,
·       Prime duration: 200,
·       Error FB duration: 1500,
·       No deadline (target appears until response).
·       ITI duration: 500
·       Targets:
o   Good words: positive, pleasant, good, outstanding, beautiful, magnificent, marvelous, excellent, appealing, delightful, nice
o   Bad words: negative, bad, horrible, miserable, hideous, dreadful, painful, repulsive, awful, ugly.
·       Primes: The 8 men names + The 8 men faces.
·       There will be a total of 16 trial conditions (each condition will repeat 4 times within each of 3 blocks) in the 2 (prime valence: positive/negative) x 2 (prime extremity: moderate/extreme) x 2 (prime practice frequency: high/low) x 2 (target category: positive/negative).

	Explicit liking rating
Participants will indicate how much they like each of the 8 men on a 1-8 scale.
Question text: How likable is X in your opinion?
Response options:
1-	Extremely Unlikable
2-	 
3-	 
4-	Not Likable nor Unlikable
5-	 
6-	 
7-	Extremely Likable
Memory test
We will tell participants that each of the 8 men was characterized by a different combination of valanced information and ask them to indicate what combination of valanced information was each man attributed.
Instruction text: Previously, we told you about six pieces of information about each of the eight men. Some men were characterized by 5 positive pieces of information and 1 neutral pieces of information, some men were characterized by 2 positive and 4 neutral pieces of information, some men were characterized by 2 negative and 4 neutral pieces of information, some men were characterized by 5 negative and 1 neutral pieces of information.
Next, for each of the eight men, please try to remember what kind of information characterized him. 

Question text: Please try to remember, what kind of information characterized this man? 
5 positive and 1 neutral pieces of information
2 positive and 4 neutral pieces of information
2 negative and 4 neutral pieces of information
5 negative and 1 neutral pieces of information

Data processing
To compute the automatic evaluation score we will subtract Log RTs of trials in which a prime (a man) preceded a good word from trials in which a prime (the same man) preceded a bad word. This priming effect is considered a measure of automatic evaluation. Because we compute this for every target individually, we will end up with 8 different scores.

Analysis plan
-	We will exclude:
-		Participants who did not remember the correct valence of all eight targets. 
-	Participants with more than 40% error-rate in the EP task.
-	EP: Trials with error responses.
-        We will enter the 8 EP evaluation scores to a 2 (level of practice: high, low) x 2 (valence: positive, negative) x 2 (extremity: extremely, moderately) ANOVA.
-        We will examine whether we find an interaction that reflects stronger effect of the valence, the more times that target was evaluated. 
-        We will enter the 8 final evaluations to the same 2 (level of practice: high, low) x 2 (valence: positive, negative) x 2 (extremity: extremely, moderately) ANOVA.
-        If we find an interaction here as well, it would mean that rehearsing the evaluation influences linking extremity.

 Power analysis (for a medium effect size (partial eta of 0.058) in a 2x2x2 within factors interaction)
We will run 350 participants, hoping to include at least 300 participants in the final analyses and achieve about 99% power to detect a medium within-factor effect of ηp2 = 0.058

 [2] 2 city, 2 country
[3] 6 city, 8 country
[4] 5 city, 1 country

Accessible vs. Extreme automatic attitudes 2 - study plan

Purpose
The purpose of the present research is to examine the effects of practice and extremity of evaluation on the automatic activation of the evaluation as measures by the EPT.

 Background
A classic finding in the field of automatic attitudes is the finding that an accessible attitude toward an object prompts an automatic activation of the evaluation upon encountering the attitude object (Fazio, Sanbonmatsu, Powell, & Kardes, 1986). One research tested the relation between accessible evaluations of nouns (e.g., divorce and baby) and the automatic activation of these evaluations (Fazio et al., 1986). In two studies, accessible evaluations were operationalized as relatively fast self-reported evaluations. In a third study, accessible evaluations were manipulated by rehearsal (evaluating a noun five different times versus making a non-evaluative judgment of a noun). Automatic evaluation was measured in an evaluative priming task. In that task, participant categorized adjectives as good or bad. Before each adjective, a noun appeared. The index of automatic evaluation of each noun was the size of the expected priming effect: faster categorization of adjectives of valence that was congruent with the valence of the prime noun than of adjectives of the other valence. attributes.title: Perceptions of Public Opinion Change
attributes.withdrawal_justification: We have been re-evaluating our plan in light of the evolving Covid-19 situation, since some of our measures may be sensitive to current events. An updated preregistration will be uploaded shortly.

attributes.title: Effekte von Fähigkeitsselbstkonzept, Selbstmitgefühl und Perfektionismus auf Arbeitsgedächtniskapazität und Lernaktivitäten nach Misserfolg
attributes.description: Dieses Projekt verfolgt das Ziel, die Effekte ausgewählter individueller Faktoren (Fähigkeitsselbstkonzept, Selbstmitgefühl, Perfektionismus) auf Reaktionen nach Misserfolgsfeedback zu untersuchen. Desweiteren wird der positive Effekt einer Intervention mit funktionalem self-talk geprüft. Als Reaktionen nach Misserfolg werden die Arbeitsgedächtniskapazität und auf Lernhandlungen bezogene Aktivitäten untersucht. Die Zielgruppe sind Lehramtsstudierende.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Bouncing/Streaming 1ms vs. 76 ms transients (matched perceived volume)

analyses.value:
Part 1: The PSE is calculated from the average of all 40 turning points.
Part 2: Paired sample t-tests comparing the 1 ms onset/offset transient tone with the 76 ms onset/offset transient tone as well as both tones against the no-tone baseline.

outliers.value:
- If the PSE estimate does not converge (e.g. the run starting high goes up or the run starting low goes down to the boundaries of the stimuli such as a minimum or maximum amplitude), the participant will be replaced.
- participants who do not vary their responses (less than 5% bouncing or streaming) in the bouncing/streaming task will be replaced.

dependent.value:
Part 1: Point of subjective equality (PSE) for perceived volume of tones with 76 ms onset/offset transients (standard) and 1 ms onset/offset transients (comparison). 

Part 2: Proportion of bouncing responses

conditions.value:
Within-subject design

Part 1: Each participant will complete four runs (standard first, start high; standard first, start low; comparison first, start high; and comparison first, start low). Based on the responses, the amplitude of the comparison is adapted in step-sizes of 0.025 until each run has reached ten turning points. 

Part 2: The participants complete a bouncing/streaming task with 1. no tone, 2. tone with 76 ms onset/offset transients (amplitude a = 0.775), and 3. a 1 ms onset/offset transient tone (amplitude matches the individual PSE observed in Part 1).

hypothesis.value:
In a previous experiment, we observed that tones with 1 ms onset/offset transients elicited more perceived bouncing than tones with 76 ms onset/offset transients. In this experiment, we test whether this effect is caused by the transients of the tones of by differences in perceived volume which go along with manipulations of the transients.

Competitive hypotheses:

1) Transient-Explanation: If the increased perception of bouncing arises from the sharp transients for the tones with 1 ms onset/offset transients, 1ms transient tones should elicit more bouncing than 76 ms transient tones.

2) Volume-Explanation: If the increased perception of bouncing arises from perceived volume, the matching procedure in Part 1 of the experiment, should eliminate the difference between 1 ms onset/offset transients and 76 ms onset/offset transients (i.e. both tones do not differ in their capability to induce bouncing). Nevertheless, both tones should elicit more bouncing than the no-tone baseline.

Within-subject design

Part 1: Each participant will complete four runs (standard first, start high; standard first, start low; comparison first, start high; and comparison first, start low). Based on the responses, the amplitude of the comparison is adapted in step-sizes of 0.025 until each run has reached ten turning points. 

Part 2: The participants complete a bouncing/streaming task with 1. no tone, 2. tone with 76 ms onset/offset transients (amplitude a = 0.775), and 3. a 1 ms onset/offset transient tone (amplitude matches the individual PSE observed in Part 1).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In a previous experiment, we observed that tones with 1 ms onset/offset transients elicited more perceived bouncing than tones with 76 ms onset/offset transients. In this experiment, we test whether this effect is caused by the transients of the tones of by differences in perceived volume which go along with manipulations of the transients.

Competitive hypotheses:

1) Transient-Explanation: If the increased perception of bouncing arises from the sharp transients for the tones with 1 ms onset/offset transients, 1ms transient tones should elicit more bouncing than 76 ms transient tones.

2) Volume-Explanation: If the increased perception of bouncing arises from perceived volume, the matching procedure in Part 1 of the experiment, should eliminate the difference between 1 ms onset/offset transients and 76 ms onset/offset transients (i.e. both tones do not differ in their capability to induce bouncing). Nevertheless, both tones should elicit more bouncing than the no-tone baseline.

attributes.title: Meaning in Life and Resilience
attributes.description: Research suggests that people who experience their lives as meaningful have higher resilience to difficulties and are better able to cope with challenges encountered in daily life (Miao & Gan, 2018; Schaefer et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2007).  However, the precise mechanisms linking meaning in life to improved resilience and effective coping strategies are unknown.  These studies will investigate meaning in life's association with adaptive coping strategies in different contexts as well as probe potential mechanisms that account for these associations.

q1.value: Sarah Ward, Jake Womick, Laura A. King, Milla Titova

q2.value:
Recalling a time when one was resilient will increase meaning in life (vs. control condition). 
Recalling a time when one was resilient will increase optimism (vs. control condition). 
Recalling a time when one was resilient will reduce perceived constraints. 
Reductions in perceived constraints will help explain why the resilience manipulation enhances meaning in life.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to write about a time they were resilient when facing an obstacle versus a control topic.  Then, they will rate current meaning in life, optimism, mood, and perceived constraints. They will also rate items assessing perceptions of their resilience to see if the manipulation exerted the intended effects.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be students in an undergraduate psychology course who opt in to doing this study and allowing us to use their data. Participants must be at least 18 years old to participate.  We will be collecting these data in late spring 2020.

q11.value: Approximately 100 participants (a full class of students) will be asked to completed this study. The exact sample size will depend on the number of participants who opt in to doing the study. If fewer than 80 participants complete this study this semester, then we will continue data collection in another class (or classes) in fall 2020, aiming to have at least 150 participants total.

q12.value: We are recruiting all students enrolled in this course in order to reach this sample size.

question.value: We are manipulating resilience. Participants will be randomly assigned to write about a time they were resilient when facing an obstacle in the past versus a control topic.  We will assess the efficacy of this manipulation with five items assessing perceived resilience.

Presence subscale of the Meaning in Life Scale (Steger, Frazier, Oishi, & Kaler, 2006)
Optimism (Scheier, Carver, & Bridges, 1994)
Mood: positive and negative affect items (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988) 
Perceived resilience manipulation check items (3 items made for study; other 2 items from Friborg, Hjemdal, Rosenvinge,  & Martinussen, 2003)
Perceived constraints (Lachman & Weaver, 1998)
Composite variables will be formed with the mean of items for meaning in life, optimism, positive/negative affect, perceived constraints, and resilience.

We will use t-tests to compare conditions on meaning in life, optimism, positive/negative affect, perceived constraints, and resilience (manipulation check).  

We will examine correlations between all study variables (within each condition and collapsing across conditions).

If the manipulation affects optimism, positive affect, or negative affect. we will use these variables as covariates in ANOVA models (or in regression models) assessing the effect of condition on meaning in life.  

We will examine if perceived constraints mediate the effect of the manipulation on meaning in life or optimism.

q19.value: We will be assessing p-values below .05 using one-tailed tests.

q20.value: Duplicate participants will be removed from the data set.

q22.value:
We will conduct exploratory analyses looking at the effect of demographic variables. 

If there is not an overall effect of condition on the meaning in life composite, we will also conduct exploratory analyses probing the manipulation's effect on each item of this composite.

q23.value: This is replication of another study we have already conducted using a different sample. We would like to test if the effects will be consistent and if perceived constraints will account for the effect of the manipulation in boosting meaning in life.

attributes.title: Functional connectivity supporting fluency
attributes.description: Lesions to the inferior frontal gyrus have often been associated with non-fluent aphasia. Though frank damage to critical language regions such as the IFG can impact behavior, the contribution of regions that are functionally, but not necessarily structurally, damaged is unclear. The described project aims to reexamine critical regions associated with speech fluency in order to determine the unique contribution of functional connections between those regions.

summary.value: A document detailing the project (hypotheses, methods, analysis plan) is attached here. This is version 1 of the project.
